conclusion: To determine if the difference in speed is continuously increasing, analyze the v-t graph.
Object A has a velocity represented by curve A; Object B by curve B.
The difference in speed is given by |v_A(t) - v_B(t)|.
At t=0, both objects start from rest, so v_A(0) = v_B(0) = 0.
Curve A starts at 0, increases to a maximum, then decreases back to 0 at t_1.
Curve B starts at 0, increases to a lower maximum than A, then decreases back to 0 at t_1.
As time increases, v_A(t) increases faster than v_B(t), so the difference |v_A(t) - v_B(t)| increases.
At the peak of curve A, v_A(t) is maximum, v_B(t) is still increasing, difference continues to increase.
After peak of A, v_A(t) decreases, v_B(t) still increases, difference continues to increase until v_B(t) is maximum.
After v_B(t) is maximum, it decreases; difference may decrease if v_A(t) decreases faster.
Difference in speed is not continuously increasing; it increases, reaches maximum, then may decrease.
Final answer: The difference in speed is not continuously increasing during the interval.
